title.rendered: New Logo, Identity, and Name for POST Luxembourg by Minale Design Strategy

content.rendered:
With roots as far as back as 1842, P&T Luxembourg (where P and T stand for Postes and Télécommunications) is (was) a state-owned corporation that handles the country’s postal service as well as telecommunications services that include land and mobile phone service, internet, and television. It also offers financial services like money transfers and cheque bank accounts. P&T had a majority ownership in LuxGSM, a mobile phone network operator and, as announced at the end of September, it will now be part of P&T, which has changed its name to POST Luxembourg, becoming the third largest employer in the country with nearly 4,000 employees and pretty much every service under the sun. The new identity has been designed by Luxembourg City-based Minale Design Strategy.

Color is the first element of recognition. It is anchored in time and reflects the integration of two very strong brands in terms of products, namely P & T (yellow and green) and LUXGSM (blue). Our colors have been preserved because they reflect our history, our roots and our position in our markets.

Identity explanation mini site (Google-translated)

Through the use of dynamic and transparent forms, the emblem symbolizes our purpose, our desire to bring individuals and businesses to position ourselves as the largest network of Luxembourg. The curves represent the permanent link we want to create between people, organizations. They include and highlight POST name. Visually dynamic, the emblem also represents the diversity of our converged solutions. In perpetual motion, it recalls the opening, another core value of our Group. The typography is resolutely modern, while remaining consistent with our traditions. This specific design is typography specially chosen. The imposing characters were chosen to support our commitment to serve our clients without discrimination, but also to achieve our goals remain the leading telecom and postal operator in Luxembourg and become a leading player in the financial sector.

Identity explanation mini site (Google-translated)

Neither of the two previous logos inspired much awe. P&T used the horn typically associated with European postal services and a retina-challenging color palette. LuxGSM had an almost-interesting techno vibe going for it, but the triple bubble icon was a bit too weird. The new logo is something that we are all probably supposed to hate at first glance. I mean, it’s a giant yellow swoosh cradling two ovals and featuring some trendy overlays and a very slight gradient. But, either I’m getting soft, or this is actually not that bad. There is a certain dynamism achieved quite well that is always the failing point of most swoosh- and overlay-based logos but this one pulls it off — specially in application where, the identity elements by themselves seem equally ill fitted to work but come together quite competently.

Between the motion pieces and the static applications, Minale has managed to infuse a good amount of layering and bold visuals to make every POST touchpoint stand out and since it seems like POST is everywhere Luxembourg is about to get a whole lot greener, yellower, bluer, and circle-er.
